description: Named after its supposed inventor, the Earl of Sandwich (see Sandwich).

entries.meaning: (US) Of a meal or serving size that is smaller than a dinner.
A dish or foodstuff where at least one piece, but typically two or more pieces, of bread serve(s) as the wrapper or container of some other food.
examples: He laid out a linen tablecloth and a few sandwichs from some bread, dressing, and beef.

entries.meaning: (by extension) Any combination formed by layering one type of material between two layers of some other material.
(UK) A layer cake or sandwich cake.
(archaic) A sandwichman (one who wears a sandwich board).
examples: We have, and not so very long ago, seen women employed as 'sandwiches'.

verbs.description: sandwich (third-person singular simple present sandwiches, present participle sandwiching, simple past and past participle sandwiched)

entries.meaning: To place one item physically between two other, usually flat, items.
(figuratively) To put or set something between two others, in time.
examples: Street BASIC is becoming the language taught in junior high; it is sandwiched between Logo, which is taught in elementary school, and Pascal, which is taught in high school.
